discourse_list.title: [Brainstorm] How do we ensure small vaults have a place at Maker?

content.content: This post is intended to offer a broader discussion on strategies MakerDAO members see fit for maintaining the ability for smaller vaults to exist. You may want to check out the conversation on the Bite Rebate Poll to inform the discussion here. The Signal Request to Increase the Dust Parameter is expected to be finalized by on-chain voting next week, raising the Dust Parameter (minimum DAI debt per vault) to 2,000 DAI. The security of the protocol is paramount, which helps explain why the Dust Parameter was just 20 DAI in August of last year and will now (probably) be 2,000 DAI just five months later. If we do not put together a plan that allows for liquidations to be preformed more cheaply, our Community will be at the mercy of Gas prices and ETH appreciation, preventing many valuable operations from people not currently in our community. I will use one last wall of text here to briefly explain why this issue is so near and dear to me. Put simply, I would not be here contributing to this vibrant and supportive community if I had found out about Maker even a couple weeks later than I did. For me, being able to test the vaults by borrowing the minimum (at the time) of 100 DAI was paramount for me being able to understand and trust the system with more of my assets. Less than a week after opening my testing vaults, the Dust Paramater was increased to 500 DAI, prompting me to join the community and start posting on the forum. I am constantly grateful that I found MakerDAO mere days before it might have slipped away from me, as I now consider this community a home and a welcome personal obsession. Seeing as the dangers of a higher Dust Parameter include:  inability for new users to “test” vaults at reasonable risk levels a barrier to entry in the DAO for contributors with less capital effectively pricing out users with a native currency weak to USD diverting market share to platforms (like Aave and Compound) without high minimums more concentrated positions from individual vault users making compatible “partner” solutions like B.Protocol more difficult to manage  And a variety of different vectors for solutions have been suggested like:  rebating keepers that call bite on undercollateralized vaults incorporating a Layer 2 solution to cut down on expenses expanding partnerships with groups like B.Protocol that offer committed liquidators updating Liquidations2.0 to be more efficient for liquidating smaller vaults moving small undercollateralized vaults to an ETH reserve fund hiring someone to manually preform bite calls  I think it’s time we start aggregating and discussing what might be a reasonable path forward. There are reasonable concerns about bandwidth and development cost, but I firmly believe the amount of vault users and contributors to MakerDAO we will gain in the long run by investing into a solution will cover those costs ten-fold. Thanks for reading and please drop your thoughts below! If you like an idea you’ve already seen in the forum, I suggest giving a tag or a linkback to draw in some discussion!

I think the answer here is for a “mega-vault” solution. A protocol (maybe @sowmay @Samyak with Instadapp or @yaronvel with bprotocol?) could open one big vault and then manage the users positions (and handle liquidations) external to Maker. content.content: There are two parts to it:  B.Protocol liquidators will be forced to liquidate, as long as they are solvent. And this will be enforced by the same tip mechanism as in LIQ-2.0. If B.Protocol liquidators are insolvent (and in particular it means they lost their initial $0.5m deposit), then it goes to the standard liquidation system.  But the liquidation of the liquidators will be simply to move them the underwater position. Meaning they will have a big vault, and it will be their responsibility to keep it solvent. It does not mean that user vault will automatically go to them, only when user vault get under water. However, this process is much cheaper gas wise. As for small positions they don’t need to hedge. And not auction mechanism is triggered. This is why lower dust level could be supported there.

content.content: To simplify the discussion, let’s say that ETH-C will be a new collateral type, backed by B.Protocol keepers. So the dust level for ETH-C could be set to a value much lower than $2k. In the event of liquidation, the B.Protocol liquidators will have to cover for the bad vault position. The experiment we offer in the RFC is to just start with low ceiling, and this way we can make sure the number of liquidators (i.e., their locked capital) fits the maximum debt. But this is currently only in RFC phase. This is not the currently deployed B.Protocol system over ETH-A.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: I’m not sure this solves the problem. The issue isn’t organic users creating small vaults, it’s the potential for an attack where one user creates tons of small vaults (I believe it was you that identified this in the first place?). In this latter scenario, if the number of liquidations exceeds B.Protocol’s Keeper pool, all of the “dusty” vaults would just end up in the normal liquidation system and we’re back at square one. Would it not make more sense to have a special Vault type, backed exclusively by B.Protocol which only allowed “dusty” vaults?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: The attack we described stem from the fact that it is very cheap (gas wise) to split your vault, and it is x10 more expensive to liquidate it (with current liquidation process). With B.Protocol the process will be cheaper (when b.protocol is the one who liquidate). If B.Protocol liquidators go default, then maker keepers will have to liquidate a big vault (the liquidator’s vault). But in any case, the ceiling of ETH-C should be such that Maker feels comfortable letting B.Protocol hadle. So say it allows initially $5m ceiling. Then an attacker cannot have bigger debt, even if he splits it to small vaults. Answering your question about supporting only small vaults. For us, as a business model it is not very appealing, as the motivation to support small Vaults is the hope the user will eventually increase his vault after he try it out for a while. A model where Maker changes its liquidation process in ETH-A, and send us all underwater small vaults for us to liquidate, would make sense. But requires much more effort on Maker side.

content.content: So pretty exciting development, @Davidutro had Yield Protocol on the Community Call today to talk about their fixed rate loan products that are built on Maker. Because of the polling and backend stuff that they are doing (i.e. interacting with Maker ETH vaults themselves rather than having their users do it), they have a minimum loan amount of less than 1 DAI. This means that small account users have somewhere to go and are still fundamentally utilizing Maker. One downside here is that Maker doesn’t get the visibility, Yield Protocol does. Check them out!    yield.is   Yield Yield Protocol brings fixed-rate, fixed-term borrowing and lending to decentralized finance.
